# Air Zone Report (2019-2021)

Air zone reports are prepared each year by the B.C. government to summarize the levels of air pollutants in broad reporting areas called "air zones". B.C. is divided into seven distinct air zones based on geography, meteorology, and political boundaries. It combines areas with similar air quality concerns in order to provide an effective process of air quality management that follows the Air Quality Management System (AQMS).

In this report, air zones are assessed for achievement of the [Canadian Ambient Air Quality Standards (CAAQS)](https://www.ccme.ca/en/air-quality-report#slide-7) and assigned colour-coded management levels. Each colour defines levels of air quality management actions that are recommended under the AQMS. In this report, the air zones are assessed for their levels of four major pollutants: fine particulate matter, ozone, nitrogen dioxide, and sulphur dioxide.

Air quality monitoring stations are found across various communities in

and assign colour-coded management levels. The assignment of management levels also defines levels of actions that are recommended under the national Air Quality Management System.

Communities in the air zones have limited control over wildfire and other exceptional events, as well as pollutants from far beyond its borders. These transboundary flows and exceptional events are presented in this report but are not included when communities and air zones are assessed for achievement of CAAQS and management levels. This helps communities focus on actions from local sources of pollution.

## Key Air Contaminants

<REPHRASE>

According to the Environmental Management Act of British Columbia, an air contaminant is a substance introduced into the air that can affect the health or safety of a person, affects visibility, can cause damage or injury to propery, lifeform, and the environment. British Columbia monitors the levels of several air pollutants that are associated with effects on health and the environment. These pollutants have various diverse sources including vehicular traffic, residential woodstoves, industrial emissions, and wildfires. There are four air pollutants that are included in an air zone reports. These are the pollutants considered to be major public health concern due to prevalence and potential to affect health.

In British Columbia, air quality has seen improvements, particularly in the levels of fine particulate matter, ozone, nitrogen dioxide, and sulphur dioxide.
